Lubricates and cleans lead screws and smooth rods.

Put the sponges in the LubriBox.

Move up and down the Z-axis to make sure everything is fine.

Have fun!

title: Holder for electric toothbrush with two positions

description.text:
My daughter loves her electric toothbrush, but there is one hitch using it. When she puts it down to close the toothpaste tube after applying the toothpaste, it would not lie upright, so the toothpaste often dropped off.
So I made her this simple holder, that holds her toothbrush, an Oral-B, in horizontal position for applying the toothpaste and also serves as a holder to give the toothbrush a home for space saving storage when not in use.
There is currently only one .STL-file, which is for this Oral-B, because We only have this one in our household to take measures from. If you send me photographs like the ones above of your toothbrush, made from some distance to avoid spatial distortion, with 1 cm graph paper behind it, I'll publish more .STLs, here.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

25% honeycomb

I used my openscad-library pointsandfaces, which is currently under development and at the same time in the middle of being documented, but sufficient enough to help me designing this. And it will be pubished, soon!
Basically this is the difference between a roundbox, that can be found under thing:2001656 and two instances of a cylinder, that is a bit shaped like the toothbrush, set in two positions.
For the cylinder I used the function cylinder_pnf_v() from pointsandfaces.
The dimensions of the toothbrush were taken manually, using photos and Corel Draw and the keyboard, to manually enter the coordinates of the points, as you can see on the photo.
The .scad file will be published at this place, as soon as pointsandfaces is published. Before this, it doesn't make sense.

author: dbfrompw

print_settings.Notes:: If your slicer supports it I'm sure the shelf would work just as well with Grid, Triangles, Stars, Cubic, and "3D Honeycomb".  I'd avoid Hilbert Curve, Archimedean Chords, and Octagram Spiral unless you go with solid top/bottom layers (aka "a solid shelf without holes").

description.text:
This is a remixed version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1114319 to make it easier to print. The original model ends up with the slicer drawing a zillion little hexagons on the print bed which requires a zillion extrusion/retractions/wipes over short distances. This can result in the extruder skipping/griding the filament (that's what happened to me anyway--it's like a printer torture test). Even if I disabled retraction it still didn't turn out well.

This version gets rid of the original hexagon-patterned shelf and replaces it with a simple solid/flat shelf. "But the pictures show a hexagon shelf!" That's right! It's just that instead of relying on the model to draw a hexagon pattern I used the slicer's "Honeycomb" infill option.
See the print settings below to see how I made it look exactly like the original despite being a "flat, solid block"!

Also: Letting the slicer draw the hexagon pattern as infill results in vastly reduced print time (only took an hour or so!) and about 9 zillion less retractions/wipes. Those hexagons in the picture were extruded as single (long) lines with very few retractions.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

13%

Notes:

If you want the shelf to look exactly like the original set your slicer (I used Slic3r) as such:

  • Fill density: 13% (you'll have to type it in)
  • Fill pattern: Honeycomb
  • Fill angle: 0° (so it lines up with the sides)
  • 0 Top layers
  • 0 Bottom layers

My shelf was printed in Inland Black PLA (the cheap stuff) with the little arm/nut parts printed in Prusa Rapunzel Silver PLA (because my first attempts in silver all failed except for the arms/nuts =).

If your slicer supports it I'm sure the shelf would work just as well with Grid, Triangles, Stars, Cubic, and "3D Honeycomb". I'd avoid Hilbert Curve, Archimedean Chords, and Octagram Spiral unless you go with solid top/bottom layers (aka "a solid shelf without holes").

I just used Blender

I imported the model into Blender and just scaled the "default cube" to fill the space of the original hexagon shelf. Took me about 30 minutes--mostly because I'm a Blender noob and had some trouble connecting edges together properly after I deleted the regular hexagon part (had to do some searches for things like, "Blender merge vertices close together" haha).

I'm sure an expert/pro with Blender would've had this little "flat shelf" conversion done in like 5 minutes (or less).

author: kilograhams

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text: Collection of BT-70 Nose Cones. Print in ABS or PET-G for the best impact strength and heat resistance. Adjust nozzle size and number of perimeters to balance strength vs weight.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 to .3

Infill:

None

Notes:

I print these in ABS or PETG for better impact resistance and less likelihood for distortion in a warm car as you will get with PLA.
The shoulders present the largest challenge in printing these. If you're using a .4 nozzle
you will need to print 4 perimeters to prevent the nosecone from collapsing at the shoulder. If you are using Simplify3D you can print the portion up to the shoulder with 3 (or 2 for lighter, less tough) perimeters, shift to 4 perimeters at the shoulder for a mm or so and then revert to 3 (or 2) perimeters. The horizontality of the top of elliptical and parabolic nose present another challenge. 1) without support they tend to collapse. 2) as the layers print more horizontally they leave gaps between adjacent perimeters. I have printed some with very sparse (3%) triangular support. The best solution I've found is to create a new process at 4-5 mm below the top with 4 top and bottom layers and 30%+ infill to provide support for the top layers. The bottom layer may be stringy depending on how well your printer bridges, but it's inside the nose cone. I also print the tops with thinner layers to reduce the stepping.

Finishing

I've tried a couple of way to make these look less like 3D parts. Acetone smoothing will work with ABS. Lately I just sand and use a filler primer to prepare to paint.
Designed in Onshape Online Cad

comments.text: Can you explain more re the different between the 28 and 30 cm version and why they are different. you mention heat bed but I don't quite understand. And hat you mean by 2 and 3 segment. also can I just confirm the sides are 3mm thick?
comments.author: sdl811

comments.text:
I have started the design with a 30 cm height enclosure. But because the spool holder can touch the upper panels at 30 cm. I have changed the design to 28 cm height. If you want the setup i am showing in the pictures you should print and laser cut the 28 cm design. In addition i have broken out the 28 cm (and 30 cm) into several segments depending on your printer printing area (should have written print area and not print bed) . The Trinus is limited to around 12 cm (printing vertical). so you need 3 segments. I have used my other printer which has larger printing volume and the 14 cm segments fitted nicely.
In any case i suggest you double check my design before fully printing / laser cutting.
For top and bottom panels i used 5mm. (top panel has 2 designs).
Side panels 3mm.

title: Mercedes W204 (and other models) carpet clip

description.text: The parts may need some adjustments (small scaling) to fit properly in existing clip in a car (depends on your printer). My advice, print first the top part and check if it fits in the car. Then print the bottom part and check if it's not too loose with the top part and not 100% tight. It has to snap under pressure (about 70kg) so it wont disconnect while unclipping the carpet.

author: presley4b

title: Ruger Standard, MK II, III, IV Pistol Charging Handle

description.text:
There's another one of these that I've found on Thingiverse, but he's using a 1/4-20 thread and I thought that 1/4" was a little too thin for this application. I redesigned the bolt puller from the ground up, redesigning the clamp to be more sturdy and I'm using a 3/8-16 thread for the knob to screw into the clamp. I have two different knobs, a cone shaped one and a knob shaped one similar to the Volquartsen bolt.

Another thing I did differently was to actually model the threads, so you don't need a tap and die, though chasing the threads with those would help things screw in smoother, but it's not necessary. To design the clamp, I created a model of the bolt, then gave the threads on the clamp a .010" clearance (the first model I printed without that clearance was a bear to get on). This is still pretty tight on the bolt, but I was able to do it without using a pair of pliers to twist it on.

In the pictures you'll also see my +1 Magazine Extension for the Mark IV. That bumps the capacity to 11 rounds.

Designed in Fusion 360, and I've included the F360 files in case you'd like to mess around with it yourself.

comments.text: For the life of me, I couldn't get the clamp to fit on my MKIII.   I ended up notching half of the angled portions of the clamp just so I could get it over the bolt.   Then it snapped off.   Also had a terrible time getting the knob threaded into the clamp.  I'm hoping that I can have a machinist friend of mine use this as reference to make one out of aluminum
comments.author: MrBrian22

comments.text: What were the dimensions that you used to create the model of the bolt/clamp? I am trying to make something similar and can't find any good information about dimensions and your clamp fits great. Any information would be appreciated.
comments.author: Niksal12

comments.text: The bolt model is included in the F360 file that I uploaded. You can just take the measurements from that.
comments.author: Niksal12

comments.text: I did see those files but I do not have fusion available to me. Would you be able to export it as a drawing?
comments.author: rezin8

comments.text: Fusion 360 is free to download and use.
comments.author: Niksal12

comments.text: Oh I did not know that. Thanks!
comments.author: rezin8

comments.text: When I open the Charging_Handle_Clamp in Cura it opens with a message that says "Auto scaled opject to 10000% of original size".  Basically it filled the width of the bed.  What is going on?  Your +1 base plate loaded in Cura fine.  I've never had this problem with Cura before after like 100 different models printed.  Actually the cone_charging_handle does it too.  The knob however loads fine.  If I look at your images it looks like they are super small based on the grids.  I was really looking forward to printing this too.
comments.author: Tripplett

comments.text: It's not the "grids". The file was created in Fusion 360 and I had switched the units to inch from mm to make it .010" over. I forgot to put it back before exporting, so the units it exported was inch rather than millimeter. Because an STL file doesn't have units in it and only numbers, Cura isn't smart enough to realize that the units were wrong. I've uploaded the correct file and you should be good to go.
comments.author: Tripplett

comments.text: It's probably my XYZ steps but when I printed the clamp it is a touch too small.  I can try a bit of sanding but if that doesn't work I'll try to print it at 101%.
comments.author: rezin8

comments.text: You want it to be a touch small so it stays put and doesn't flop around. The bolt is sharp, you can use a pair of pliers and twist it on and it'll cut into the PLA and make it fit perfectly.
comments.author: Tripplett

comments.text: Where the heck did you get the idler pulleys?  The M4 ones I have were too thick to fit in the spot.  It's designed for M5, which I imagine is going to be just as big if not bigger. Perhaps I'd just flatten the protrusions out completely and use washers instead.

title: Accessoires for Quick Clamps from bessey festool, piher, juuma

description.text:
Use your FS-guide rail quick clamps for other purposes with these Accessoires.
Just slide on the top cap and you can use the clamps also without the FS-guide-rail just like any traditional forged clamp.

My clamps came without protective pads on the excenter pad, so they leave imprints on softer wood. So i made my own PLA-pads which fit snugly. You have to heat them to get them on, and they wont come off easily like some original caps do.

Feel free to use the Rhino .3dm file to adjust if they don't fit your printer/settings or for remixes.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100micron

Infill:

0.1-0.3

Notes:

Printed in PLA on my UM2 with "normal quality" settings, standing vertically without support, raft or brim.
I use a 60° heated glass plate primed with 3Dlac for the build surface and it works fine even without a brim. The sticking surface is very thin vertically, but allows for large multiprints.

Printed on the UM2 it exactly fits the t-rail of the clamp. The friction fit is enough not to come off accidentally.
I included another design that uses a spring-like mechanism for increased friction on the clamp, you may try this on other printers if the normal version fits too loose.

You want to use PLA for this, because it is resistive to most solvents that may be in glue or paint that you use on the clamped pieces.

When printing without a brim, deburring is not necessary.

Reheat the lower pads with a hot air gun to fit them snuggly on your clamps.

description.text:
My wife puts her hair in a ponytail often and has a lot of Scunci loops. They aren't really organized, and it's hard for her to find the right one. Putting them in a drawer doesn't work, because she will have to dig constantly to find one. Putting them on a pole doesn't work, because invariably she will have to pull half the scuncis off the pole to get at the one she wants.

A ring makes the most sense to me, so I designed this (complete with stylish hook). I've split it into 4 pieces to (hopefully) fit on a normal sized print bed. It will require gluing after printing and an M5 pan-head bolt and nylock nut to hold the hinge together.

While congratulating myself on my clever design and mastery of Fusion 360's joint feature, I realized I'd just re-invented the Shower Curtain Ring, except I super-sized it. Sigh.

Edit: March 19 (V7) - added draft for nut and bolt features, and made them deeper. Tweaked profile around hinge. Added radius to sawtooth split points to make gluing easier.

title: SolarRoboFlower Kit 1.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Remember Daniels cool SolarRoboFlower?
We made a kit out of it and a new design for the acrylic parts.

Please check out the detailed assembly instructions found here http://instructions.hackerspaceshop.com/solarroboflower1.1/ Daniel and I put together a complete kit with over 130 parts needed to assemble a solarroboflower yourself.
We also made custom electronics and wrote a new firmware.
Check it out in our shop found here http://http://www.hackerspaceshop.com/robotics/solarroboflower-kit We also sell a version of the kit without the acrylic parts if you have your own lasercutter that can be found here http://www.hackerspaceshop.com/robotics/solarroboflower-noacryl-parts.html Make sure to use 3mm acrylic that was EXTRUDED because there are quite sophisticated snap and interlock mechanisms built into this kit and the materialtolerance is set for only 5%.. VIDEO: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=egF929u2DCk

title: OpenLock 5.0 Tudor Wood Column O Post Pillar

description.text:
OpenLock 5.0 Column "O" Tudor style Wood Post or "Pillar"
A good aspect of this version, is the "Column" piece. With this piece, you can turn an "A" style wall into a "C" (left or right hand version) or using 2 Column "O", you can create a "D" wall piece. This allows fewer 3d prints to add to your collection. Just print 4 "A" walls and you can, at anytime, have one of 4 different wall types. One style across 4 types and use as a standard "A" type.

Only created the "O" column, as I do not see the need for the other types, in this instance, and this opens up options for multi-use, two level half-walls to mix and match in the future.

Kudos to Printablescenery
http://www.printablescenery.com/product-category/rampage-system/
Rampage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821631
OpenLock 4.0 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963

OpenLOCK columns and side locking walls
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2098287
and DevonJones OpenForge

remixed_from.author: phenoptix
remixed_from.title: MeArm V0.4 - Pocket Sized Robot Arm

description.text:
This is my contribution to meArm ( robotic arm )
Original files: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:360108

I have joined several and different original parts to simplify the design. Original parts were designed to use a laser cutter, but the 3D printed result is a bit cumbersome, and parts didnt fit the way they were supposed to do.

In this design, the " box" of the arm is composed of 3 pieces.
In addition, servos adjust into parts has been improved, and now servos fit perfectly.
On the other hand, a "bearing" for the whole arm has been added to the original design.
Last but not least, the clamp holder is a new idea.

These changes produce a simpler plate set to be printed, and an easy way to assemble the arm.

The full set is compound of: Plate_base, plate_claws,plate_sticks and plates_ladder.

I will try to make a pdf with assembling instructions asap. Meanwhile, clean the bed and print the full set.

My starting point was merely the set of stl parts in meArm v0.4 ( see link above )
Then I used OpenScad to join the "box" of meArm,.
A new design produced thre single pieces.
The base of the "box" was redesigned as a "bearing".

I tried to keep the original parts when possible. I will probably end up redesigning all the parts. Parts to be redesigned are just a handful, and the task is not a difficult one, but now we have a final product.

2017-August
Modified SG90 servo parts ( The SG90 hole in the parts was too small )
Added file: AssemblyManual.pdf A full detailed handbook to drive you from the 3D plates to the model.
2017-May
Version 0.1

Can you make the pieces available in separate files?
the printing area of my machine is very small

title: Airsoft Belt Buckle Claymore
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is my claymore belt buckle for airsoft !
Need I say more ?

You will need a mouse trap and m3 screws

it works like a (half) regular rat trap claymore.

Cut the wood from the mouse trap to fit inside the body, add cloth (or tape) from the metal moving part to the wood body, it should form a rectangle triangle viewed from the side when the trap is open

Use m3 nuts and bolts + glue to assemble everything
For the trigger use a thin metal wire (from a paper clip or from discarted parts of the mouse trap).

description.text:
Indoor Garden project that I created in order to grow Kuroda carrots.

The bottom of the pod is designed to house water in the event that over watering happens. The pods will have to be sanded down and painted/sealed in order to house the product.

Supplies:
-Seeds (https://www.seedsnow.com/products/carrot-kuroda-8-long)
-Grow Light (https://www.amazon.com/MarsHydro-Spectrum-Certification-Hydroponic-Greenhouse/dp/B00XC3LBI2/ref=sr_1_7?s=lawn-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1489599068&sr=1-7&keywords=led+grow+light)
-Filament (http://www.3dfuel.com/product-tag/apla-1kg/)
-Moisture & PH Sensors (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01IOS7WIW?ref_=ams_ad_dp_asin_2)
-Squeeze Bottle (https://www.amazon.com/Degree-Liquid-Holder-Squeeze-Bottle/dp/B00LGJ0UDQ/ref=sr_1_2?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1489599189&sr=1-2&keywords=water+bottle+lab)
-Lumber (how ever big you wan the table to be)
-Super Glue
-Water Jug
-Floor Mat
-Dirt (research the seeds specific needs)
-Plastic Spray Paint
-Plasti-dip

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Z18

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300

Infill:

10

Notes:

Any resolution or infill would be fine.

Post-Processing

1) Sand pods down with 60 or 80 grit paper then move to 120 or 200 grit
2) Spray paint with plastic spray paint
3) Spray plasti-dip

Fusion360

Designed in Fusion360 with a chamber at the bottom to allow for water to flow if over-water occurs. Slant in top is for cosmetic effect

remixed_from.author: devonjones
remixed_from.title: OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs

title: OpenLock 5.0 Tudor Wall A -Chevron Styles Wood

description.text:
OpenLock 5.0 Wall "A" Tudor style Wood Chevron Styles
With this group, the start of the remix of Devon Jones OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs. This wall will work with OpenLock 5.0 Tudor Wood Column O Post Pillar http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179339 to turn this "A" style wall into a "C" (left or right hand version) or using 2 Column "O", you can create a "D" wall piece. This allows fewer 3d prints to add to your collection. Just print 4 "A" walls and you can, at anytime, have one of 4 different wall types. One style across 4 types and still use as a standard "A" type.

Took the OpenForge 5.0 Bool Tool and matched with my base tile. Added wood texture to the outside of the base, in case this was to be a second floor wall. Shrunk the wall to 8mm thick as this was the standard floor tile thickness, and as the wall was thinner than the base added wood texture to the top of the base. This did not work, unless the print was of high quality, because of the wall thickness next to the OpenLock vertical slots. Thus this version 2.0, the Tudor wall is now 9mm thick and should work at lower print settings for speed.

This is a concept that I had been working on, thinner Tudor walls with wood post end caps to allow proper fitting, like the mid-wall styles that Printable Scenery has designed with their Rampage System. As Printable Scenery came out with the 5.0 precursor design files, it fit into what I wanted to accomplish in a more elegant way. I still may offer a thinner inner wall version like what I had first envisioned.

The top "nubs", I am not sold on, and have modified to fit the OpenLock 5.0 standard AND my odd base size, so this wall will stack on itself, but not on the OpenLock 5.0 wall, but an OpenLock 5.0 wall can stack upon this wall, thus this is still a work in progress.
Have printed the Chevron Down version, as shown, and at 2 different layer heights. One layer height print does not work (don't remember which) but an easy fix is to take a drill bit and "carve" out the base for the pegs to work better.
Kudos to Printablescenery
http://www.printablescenery.com/product-category/rampage-system/
Rampage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821631
OpenLock 4.0 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963
OpenLock 5.0 (pre-release columns)
OpenLOCK columns and side locking walls
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2098287
and DevonJones OpenForge
OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1641003

03/17/17 Added additional Chevron Styles to this upload to simplify downloading.

author: Start2

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6RYfpQCIZ0w

Current Version 2.1 - 9/21/2017

All screw holes are for #8's

I have seen a lot of different spool holders out there and none of them have been able to give me exactly what I'm looking for. Below is a list of things I'm trying to achieve with this build.

Latest Changes - 11/20/2017

  • Uploaded a new picture showing this mount also works on other enclosures besides just Lack Tables! :)
  • Fixed Bearing Bracket 1 to remove gap in print that was found by paparazzi.

Objectives:

  • Adjustable to accommodate different spool widths
  • A more permanent solution that will not move easily
  • Easily mod-able ( Using different style holders when I come up with something new )
  • Print without the need for supports / rafts
  • Use 608 bearings

Currently Looking into:

comments.text: Why have two diferent Bearing Brackets? Why now one bracket with a pin and a hole? It will be symetrical. Also is there any difference between Left bracket and Right bracket?

comments.text: The difference between the two is on the very bottom have a notch and key to help keep them together. I also wanted the design to be able to print with no supports and also to allow the bearings to be pinched in the middle to allow the spool to roll very easily.

description.text:
This is a 6 inch diameter Geometry manipluative that can be useful in the teaching and learning about the properties of angles, inscribed angles, central angles, and arc lengths and measures. Use with a rubber band or two to discover the relationship between inscribed and central angles . Holes around circumference are spaced at 15 degree intervals, with a total of 24 lines equally radiated around the center.

If planning on using this to complement lessons on the subject, print a classroom set so each student can explore, or at least print enough so that each table group can share one.

Additional materials needed:

  • rubber bands
  • 25 small nails ( i used some 5/8" nails I had in my workshop - see photo) to tap into holes (24 around edge and one in center)
  • hammer

If you like this object, check out the customizable version I created at:

title: ZMR250 FPV Camera with integrated OSD and Tilt-Mount

description.text:
Housing for a 600TVL CCTV/FPV camera from ebay/Banggood.
The OSD (MicroMinim-OSD) is also directly integrated into the housing.

It's intended to be mounted onto the Camera Plate of a ZMR250 with the Tilt-Mount but you can just break of the tabs of the Camera Housing and use it standalone.

Assembly

Camera Housing
There are three wires from the camera (Just cut the one for Audio). On the Micro-MinimOSD there is a row with Through-Holes. Route the Video-Wire through the DTR hole, 5V through 5V and GND through GND.
Solder the Video_Wire to Video-IN on the OSD. Cut the Power wires as close to the OSD-PCB as possible and solder them on. The rest of the connections should be clear.
To seal everything of just add a layer of Epoxy-Resin.

Tilt-Mount
There are markings on the mounts every 15°.
To secure them to the Carbon-Plate just stick the small pins through the holes. Melt them and press them flat. Just like a Rivet

comments.text: Nice design. Micro minimOsd does get pretty hot.. Was it ok inside epoxy?
comments.author: juha_j

comments.text: I plugged the Camera in for about half an hour and it did only get warm, not hot, maybe around 35°C. Picture didn't show any distortion and OSD was working fine. I think that during a flight it won't even get warm.

description.text:
Turn your iPhone 6s Plus into a magnifying glass / overhead projector.

This design is a bit random I know, but it may be of use to somebody.

I have eyesight problems (technically I am classed as Severely Sight Impaired) and it dawned on me that I have the perfect magnifying glass built into my iPhone. This stand allows you to support your iPhone and by using the Camera and AirPlay functions project the image onto a PC Monitor or TV (I'm using AirServer software on the PC to transmit the signal from the phone to the monitor). The stand has a cut out for the power lead and is designed so that it will fit the phone with its case still on.

This was my first stab at the design and it isn't perfect just yet (but does what I need it to for now). I plan on supporting the phone further away from the target object and modifying the design so that any phone could be used.

comments.text: Do you have a HDMI adapter on the iPhone connecting to the monitor?

title: Filament Spool Holder - Prusa i2/i3 style

description.text:
Filament spool holder/stand, with Prusa i2/i3 look.

Metal parts needed:
8x threaded rod M8x210mm
16x M8 nut
16x M8 washers
1x linear shaft dia. 8mm x 210mm

Additionally, 4x M8 nuts and 4x M8 washers can be used (for the standing rods), but its not required.

If you want to make longer stand - use 2x longer threaded rods and longer linear shaft (same length)

Threaded rods can be also printed, but I strongly recommend buying metal ones, as they are cheap.

You can also use threaded rod for the top and a additional spool holder made by rowokii, this will fit this stand as its based also on 8mm rod and 608zz bearing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767317
With longer stand and this configuration you can set more spools working independently - to use with eg. multicolor printer.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

It's better to rotate top 90 degree around X axis before printing (lying down on side)

After finishing building printer with bowden style extruder I started to wonder where and how I should put the filament spool. Then I started to look for stands - found a lot of them, but I didnt enjoyed any.
I had M8 threaded rods and some linear shafts left from building prusa clone somewhere around me - so I decided to use it, and make a minimalistic design allowing to build fast the filament stand/holder.

Step 1

Use 8mm drill to make sure side holes have correct size.
Drill ONLY the side holes, otherwise stand will be unstable (but still working)

Step 2

On 4 threaded rods insert 8 nuts and 8 washers, as on image below.
If you want to make longer stand, use 2 longer threaded rods and 2x210mm.

Step 3

Insert rods with nuts into corners.
If you are making longer stand, put the longer rods in the holes without recess for washer.

Step 4

Insert 4 rods without nuts into tops

Step 5

Insert 8 washers and 8 nuts on outer sides of all corners

Step 6

Insert parts with tops to the base and tighten all the nuts

Step 7

Put the linear shaft on top of the construction

Additional steps

If you want, you can also put a washer and nut on the rods from standing part, but it will be only for appearance.
You can also replace the top linear shaft with a threaded rod, and use additional spool holder.

description.text:
Whenever we occasionally had to tie our dog to his retractable leash inside the house, one problem we observed was that the leash would reach above the table and knock over the stuff on it (such as the red vase pictured above). I therefore decided to come up with a solution that would route the leash downwards from the staircase railing, so that it would reach below the table.

I designed this piece in OpenSCAD. It consists of a two-piece clamp, attached together using two M3 35mm screws, as well as an empty space for the leash to go through. This space has a thin slanted slit at the front, so that the leash can easily be placed in and taken out. It also has a fillet at the bottom so that the leash can slide more easily.

This seems to work very well. It does add quite a bit of friction, but our dog doesn't seem to have much difficulty pulling on the leash.

title: Prusa Mk2 IKEA Dioder rear mount

description.text:
Tired of not seeing your beautiful i3 print?
Don't sit around, slap an IKEA Dioder strip on your Prusa!
Choose between the single, dual or triple mount.
Print 2 of the chosen mounts and your Dioder strip will sit nicely behind the vertical frame and has enough clearance with your Spool holder and filament guide.

I soldered the wires of the Dioder to an unused output of the 12V power supply. This way they will power on and off together with the printer, but are semi-independent. Solder the R, G, and B wires together and screw into to the -12V terminal. Screw the +12V (W) wire from the LED strip to the +12V terminal.

The 003 models all point toward the center of the build plate location. The 004 SpreadLight version spreads the light distribution over the entire build plate.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2 Original

No

No

0.2

25%

Print in PLA, ABS, PETG or other stiff material.
I used 2 perimeters with 25% honeycomb infill.

This module works in the trigonometric circle. As a reminder and without wishing to offend you, the trigonometric circle has its 0 which corresponds to the x-axis and its direction of rotation is counterclockwise.
The start value should ever been lower than end value.
In v2, I added a check up of the start and end values to avoid some issues with the computations. I have improved the processing of the angles and reduced the number of polygons to draw to open the circle.
You can use it as a module in your project or include it in your library.

• The received angles are checked to convert them if necessary in accordance with the operation of the trigonometric circle.
  • The opening angle is divided into a minimum of angles less than 45 °
  • The height of each triangle is calculated to be larger than the outer circle
  • A loop draws the triangles from the start value to the end value in the difference scope
  • The triangles overlap by 2 ° which is the lower limit of treatment.

title: PIRANHAZ ABS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A slim version of the PIRANHAZ (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1734347) to be printed with ABS.

I cut the thing in two pieces, printed them both and then glued them together. This can be done with any program that can edit STL files, e.g. Blender, MeshMixer or any other program. I did it with IceSL that is similar to OpenSCAD but the scripting language is lua and all objects are rendered in realtime.

I didn't include any STL as the license of the PIRANHAZ thing doesn't allow the redistribution of remixes. To make sure you remember this I selected the same license here.

The attached lua file can be opend in IceSL, but you'll have to adjust the path to the original thing (drag and drop it into the text editor and you'll have the path). This script takes a few slices of the original thing, and puts them together to a very slim piranha (2.6mm, the original has 9mm). The bite force of this slim model is moderate. If you need more force simply make it thicker. The STL can be exported and sliced with your favorite slicer, theres no need to use the internal slicer of IceSL.

Printer:

Qidi Avatar IV

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Cleanup task if necessary:
-Most likely the levers did glue partially to the body (due to the very thin design). It should be possible to break them free without much effort using a small screwdriver or knife. Then you should have two working parts.

Gluing the two parts together:
-Use any appropriate glue. I always use acetone (read and follow the safety instructions) to ABS. Apply a very thin film to each part and then put the parts together.
(Acetone dissolves ABS, don't use too much. If you don't have experience with the glue try it on some spare material, just to make sure that you know how to apply the appropriate amount of glue.)

comments.text: 228°C and 40 mm/s, I found that if I try and print too fast, the flexible filament bends and folds up between the drive gear and hot-end. I could probably increase the print speed some, but I would rather have the print take slightly longer than to risk having it fail.

print_settings.Notes:: ABS, black, avoid bright colors that tend to attract bees.

description.text:
This is an ant barrier device to keep ants out of a bee hive. 4 are required. Each is designed to mount on a four inch 3/8-16 threaded rod. The lower part of the ant barrier will hold mineral oil. All gaps are 1/2". In order to enter the hive, the ant climbs the threaded rod, climbs the oil cup then is confronted with a 1/2" wide pool of oil. The ants cannot cross the oil so cannot enter the hive. These have been 100% effective at keeping ants out of my hive. The cover is designed to discourage bees from entering the ant barrier. It should be printed in black in order not to attract bees. The central holes are 3/8" but I found I could thread the plastic so the threaded rod will hold the parts in position. A hex nut can be used under the ant trap. The threaded rod should extend at least 1/2 inch below the assembled ant trap to keep ants from climbing directly to the outside cover.

The rods mentioned above are part of a hive stand. The hive stand is made from inexpensive two foot sections of 1/2" and 3/8" rebar from a home supply store. The rebar is welded to support the hive. On each corner of the welded a 3/8-16 hex nut was welded. The threaded rod threads vertically into the hex nut and supports the hive. This hive stand was initially made to easily level the hive and to provide an unobstructed space under the hive. Later this ant barrier was designed in order to keep ants from entering the hive. A few ants can be handled by the bees. We had a number of starter hives with 3 pound bee packages (1 queen, 3 lbs bees, approximately 10,000 bees) which were overrun by ants. They not only take the honey, they carry off the bee larvae.

I printed in ABS, resolution 0.2mm The STL files are in inches so to change to mm, scale by 25.4

description.text:
I will need to get revised photos up of the new layout! I made this from scratch for my Mom's iPad 2. Its five pieces that press fit together. The H support member, is printed in two halves that have to be glued together then placed in the upper hole of the S curve's. The base could be refined.

I revised the base and the H member so once constructed, you can flatten the contraption. Next, The long rod should be threaded through the base holes and bottom holes of the support S curves. You can heat the ends of the rod for flattening the ends so it doesn't come apart...or leave it loose for deconstruction and portability.

I know its, big, and not very expedient (5 hr print approx) but for Mom with clumsy fingers, it works great. I coated the bottom of the base with liquid rubber (Dipit) so it grips the surface of the table for safer and better iPad, iPhone support.

Notes:

prints straight away. There might be a problem with the halves of the H support member not adhering to the bed. I would print with hot nozzle and coolish bed, say 212 for the Nozzle and 40 degrees for the Bed. I also laid out the H member halves so they don't have deal with extreme elevations, by laying them out like the rods, of which there are two. A short for placing the iPad support S curves inside the frame, and a longer rod for placing them on the outside of the frame, in which case, don't glue together the H member, as you won't be able to use as a lever to keep the angle of slant intact. Some experimenting will be necessary.

You need to press fit the H member and Thread the Rod....

Glue the two halves of the H member support together. The long rod gets threaded as shown through the bottom of the S curves and the frame front hole provided for it. There is a bit of looseness and play, but that's ok. The swivel and middle indent makes for a perfect stand.

To finish, I got some liquid rubber (Dipit) at the hardware store and coated the bottom of the frame; so it would stick to, and not slip on a desk or tabletop surface. You can seal the ends of the rod so the support S curves don't come apart as indicated above, by heating the ends and flattening with a knife or some such.

I made a nice curve....

I started with the curve, imagined the frame. Did some boolean operations to make the indent in Rhino along with the rods which I had a lot of trouble printing. Maybe you have some suggestions?

The whole thing fit together once I reprinted the rods and H member to be smaller.

description.text:
Apparatus to hold flat neodymium magnets (2 x 1 x 1/16 in.). This creates a moderately uniform magnetic field between the magnets and the whole apparatus can be placed on a scale. Placing a wire segment with a horizontal current flow between the magnets will exert a force proportional to the current according to the Lorentz Force Law (for straight wires):

                               

Force = (current)*(length of horizontal wire) cross-product (Magnetic Field).
The wire should be shaped like a U with a flat bottom. In order to stay within the uniform portion of the field the horizontal segment of wire should be ~1 in and turn at right angles upward at the ends so as not to contribute to the force calculation (the two opposite vertical components result in equal and opposite forces in the horizontal direction). This can be used to measure the magnetic field between the magnets. Also the top of the apparatus can rotate so that the dependence on the angle in the cross-product can be seen.

Example magnets this will hold:
http://www.magnet4sale.com/n45-2x1x1-16-neodymium-rare-earth-block-magnet/

Notes:

  1. The fasteners may break when dropped or if not careful during assembly but they're so small just print an extra.
  2. For moderate currents of ~5 amps your scale needs to be sensitive on the order of tenths of a gram.
  3. Print orientation is the largest flat surface down, so top piece is right side up, bottom and fastener are upside down, layer thickness 0.15

0.15

remixed_from.title: 3D Catan Fog Hexes for Seafarers Expansion

title: 3D Catan Resource Token for Seafarers Expansion

description.text:
I made these tokens to be used while playing the 3D Settlers of Catan Seafarers Expansion. Specifically with the fog island scenario. In this scenario you're supposed to flip the cardboard hexes over to be the fog pieces, but that's a little hard when your hexes are 3-dimensional.

To get around this I modified the existing water hex to be the fog hex (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1250103). Once the fog hex is discovered and removed, the player should blindly draw a token from a cup to see what the fog was covering. If it's a resource, then they should also draw a number from a separate cup.

The fog hexes also have resources on the bottom, but I was paranoid people would memorize the paint job of the gold hexes so I made these to be used with the fog.

The number of tokens required depends on the exact scenario and player version for the board setup. Just check the scenario setup in the rules.

There are multiple versions of water and gold depending on what style you like.

Be sure to check out my other Catan designs in my profile.

author: Popsicle_peon

title: E3D Sensor mount for the Hypercube

description.text:
An easier and tighter way to mount the LJ12A3-4-Z Inductive Proximity Sensor to the Hypercube 3d printer.

Note. You might find it too loose or tight and need to scale it a bit smaller or larger to fit your probe. Best to test before mounting it to the main e3d x-axis mount. Clip it in and out a few times before hand.

Parts

Uses the same screw size fitting as the original mount. (M3 screw)

Directions

My approach is to move nozzle down at the centre of the bed (about a paper width away) and use a 1mm steel ruler to set the height of the probe before clipping it on.

Clip in the sensor at the desired height and then tighten the nuts to put firmly in place.

I use `m48 p10 x100 y100 v2 e l2 to test the repeatability of the probe

More info - https://github.com/pflannery/Hypercube/blob/master/auto-leveling.md

Tools

I use and recommend getting a Hex Screw driver tool kit and a Hex Nut key Socket Screw driver tool kit too. I have sets made by E-Sky but you can search for them at banggood or ali-express for cheaper

description.text: Ok

This is 3D printer friendly design of panel mount USB connector. One simple PCB is required.Gerbers are within the ZIP file. It is meant for housing mount USB cable. It will probably cause USB communication troubles, but in case it works, it's nice feature to add USB to the external housing.

Assembly is simple. Two M4 screws are required. Just solder the cable to the PCB with proper pinout, press both parts together and fasten to the housing. Two holes for M4 screws and one square hole for USB connector is required. The template is shown in attached step files.

description.text:
For owners of fancy antique tea-cups, one can buy little display stands similar to this for silly prices, like $10-20. Sounds like a job for 3D printing. Rather than re-create one of the commercial designs, I designed my own from scratch and you can print a couple of them for less than the price of a cup of coffee.

I refined my initial design a couple of times and ended up with something nicely stable and functional. No printing supports required.

With about 25% fill, it comes out nice and light (20g), and yet stable enough that even with a bit of a bump, it'll hold the saucer okay. I haven't translated this into an earthquake rating - but I'm guessing you're okay up to about a Richter M5.6 at least.

Excuse the marginal grey-PLA print among the example photos - had some filament feed problems so it was a bit stringy. :( The translucent PLA material worked out perfectly.

In testing, I see that different saucers will sit at different angles. With a bit of a camber to the rear support face, this design seems to accommodate all I could find quite well. I'm sure there's a traditional Lithuanian saucer or a Nigerian chalice plate that will be terribly incompatible though, so no promises that it'll work for everyone.

Use at your own risk - I'm not responsible for Grandma's priceless tea set if you try this and break anything. :)
